row.cell:
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.
To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.
STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
Le réseau de cable télégraphiques sous-marins de cette compagnie
constitue le moyen de communication le plus
direct et le plus rapide d'Egypte pour l'Europe, l'Amérique
du Nord et du Sud, L,Afrique orientale, méridionale
et occidentale, les Indes, l'Australie, la Nouvelle-Zélande, la
Chine et le Japon.
Pour assurer une transmission rapide, les télégrammes
doivent porter l'indication Viâ Eastern.
Voir le temps moyen de transmission le plus récent jusqu'à
Londres au belletin journalier publié dans ce journal.
STATIONS EN EGYPTE. Alexandrie, le Caire, Suez,
Port-Tewfik, Port-Said, Suakin. Bureau principal à Londres.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

FRIDAY, DECEMBER 30, 1904.

div.head: THE PILGRIMAGE.
div.p:
The ceremony of the Kisweh, which takes place to-morrow, is a significant reminder of the approach of the annual pilgrimage. Various considerations arise, amongst them being the somewhat important one of finance. According to the regulations, which were recently issued, it would appear that there is to be some increase, and in the case of third-class passengers a considerable augmentation, in the deposit to cover cost of conveyance to be demanded by the Government. This year LE 25 has to be deposited for the first-class, L.E. 22 for the second-class and L.E. 18 for the third-class. The charges, taken as a whole, appear to us to be too high. From enquiries that we instituted on a previous occasion, it was found that a pilgrim, who even took the longest route, could manage to go to the Holy Places and back for a sum much smaller than that which is now exacted. Besides which, he was not put to the inconvenience of making any deposit, but could make his own bargains and could pay the money as the occasion demanded. In a year when there is no reason to expect any infectious disease to emanate from the usual sources, there is no valid reason for the exaction of a larger sum as a deposit than the actual passage money, which from Jeddah is a mere pittance. We have never yet been able to discover the advantages which pilgrims have derived by the Government insisting upon a change of route. To us it has always appeared an unwarrantable interfere
AUFGEBOT.
Es wird zur allgemeinen Kenntnis ge bracht, dass 1. der Kolooillwaren Grosshaendler Karl
Ludwig Eduard Schneider, wohnha f zu Alexandrien in Aegypten, Sohn des in Pforzheim wohnhaften Privatie & Hermann Schneider und sei. ner verstorbenen Ehefrau Em lie geb. Rothacker, Zuletzt wohnhaft in Pforzheim 2. und die Else Jenny Pastor, obne Beruf, wohnhaft zu Crefeld
Tochter des Samtfabrikanten Karl Pastor und seiner Ehefru Anna geb. Tecklenburg,
beid wohnhaft in Crefeld
die ihe mit einander eingeben wollen.
Die Bekanntmachung des Aufgebots hat in den Gmeinden Crefeld und Alerandrien zu geschehen. Crefeld, ad 19ten Dezember 1904.
Der Standesbeamte In Vertretung
JACOBS.
ence with the liberty of the subject, against which we have not failed to enter aforetimes our earnest protest. If sanitary reasons are alleged as a justification, then any possible contamination would be avoided by a thoroughly strict quarantine at Tor. To this we have every reason to believe no opposition would be offered by those attending the pilgrimage. That difficulty is therefore easily surmounted. But another reason has been put forward for the stringency of the regulations, and that is that the pilgrims should receive adequate protection. The precautions that are to be taken this year owing to the increase of the escort may possibly be adequate, but considering that Arabia is by no means in a tranquil state, there are not sufficient guarantees against a petition of the terrible scenes which occurred during last year's pilgrimage.

div.head: THE OFFICIAL JOURNAL
div.p: The National Printing Office is advertising a sale of waste paper for the year 1905, amounting to three or four tons a month, but that does not include the regular publication of the Journal Officiel, which does waste a great amount of paper. The Journal Officiel sadly needs reform in economising space. The Survey Department notices could not be made shorter and still maintain the clear tabular form which shows at a glance all the information to be conveyed. The Custom House lists are equally clear. The Public Works public general conditions of contracts and the special contracts follow, but in these there is far too much repetition of information which might be given once for all. The Post Office Wastes space over lost Savings Bank books. The Railway Administration do not open a small telegraph office or stop a train at an additional station without inordinate announcement. The Ministry of Finance, when they sell a few feddans of land, usually spread themselves. If they had general conditions announced once in each publication of the Journal it would not matter, but for each sale there is endless reiteration and the real matter is concealed and buried, Worst of all, when one has waded through a long notice to find what is really being sold, there is only a number indicating the lot, and one is referred to the Journal Officiel No. 99 of 6th Sept. 1902 for the clauses and conditions of sale. The Same Ministry, in letting land, makes clear tabular statements. "Words, words, words; quoth Hamlet, but more method in the madness would save busy people time and trouble. If the Official Journal were run on more commercial lines and useless matter kept in abeyance, a great improvement would be effected.

div.head:
ERHLUNG-SHAN.
FORT CAPTURED,
TREMENDOUS BOMBARDMENT.
A BITTER FIGHT.

div.p: The Japanese occupied the entire fort of Erhlung-shan yesterday.
(Reuter.)

Reuter's correspondent with the besiegers states that when the Japanese captured Erhlung-shan Fort they had 1,000 casualties. Seven dynamite mines were exploded at 10 o'clock yesterday morning, breaches thus being made in the front wall, through which a large body of troops charged, uuder cover of a tremendous bombardment. They captured the first line of guns, and a bitter fight then ensued, which resulted in the capture of the whole fort by night-time. The garrison consisted of 500 men, of whom a third escaped. (Reuter.)
A further casualty list shows 49 officers killed and 58 wounded. These figures, coupled with yesterday's list, indicate the severity of the losses in the rank and file. (Reuter.)
After a desperate fight on Wednesday, the Japanese occupied Erhlung-shan fort. (Havas.)

div.head:
SEIZURE OF THE "NIGRITIA.”
RUSSIANS ON BOARD.

div.p: According to a telegram from Sasebo, the captain and a lieutenant of the Russian destroyer "Raztorpny" were identified on board the S.S. "Nigritia," which was seized by the Japanese on the 20th inst.
(Reuter.,

div.head: MOVEMENTS OF JAP SHIPS.
div.p: Several Japanese warships have passed New Anjer.
(Reuter.)

div.head:
NORTH SEA INQUIRY.
CHANGE OF RUSSIAN REPRESENTATIVE

div.p: Admiral Kaznakoff, Russian representative on the Inquiry Tribunal, is returning home. Vice-Admiral Dubassoff has been appointed to replace him. The reason of the recall of the former is not stated.
Admiral Skrydloff, commanding the Vladivostok squadron, is also returning home. (R.)
The Municipality here has resolved to petition for the convening of a congress consisting of the representatives of all the municipalities in Russia.
(Reuter.)

div.head:
BRITISH ARMY.
BIG ORDER FOR GUNS.

div.p: The War Office yesterday placed orders with Messrs. Armstrong and Vickers Maxim for 18- pounders sufficient to rearm the whole army
(Reuter.)

div.head:
FRANCE AND SIAM.
M. DELONÇLE TO INTERPELLATE.

div.p: M. Deloncle, in a letter to the Temps; protests against the evacuation of Chantabun before the delimination provided for in the treaty is completed. He will interpellate the Government as early as possible, in connection with this disregard of the provisions of the treaty and the express wishes of Parliament.
(Reuter.)
Herr von Koerber, President of the Council of Ministers, has resigned.
(Havas.)
M. Delyannis has formed a new Cabinet with M. Skovzes as Foreign Minister. (Reuter.)
M. Delyannis is President of the new Cabinet and M. Skouzes Minister for Foreign Affairs,
(Hanga.)

div.head:
SOUTH AFRICA.
BOERS AND REPRESENTATIVE GOVERNMENT.

div.p: At a conference between Lord Milner and the Boer leaders after Mr. Kruger's funeral, his Lordship proposed a scheme for representative government embracing all parties. There were to be 24 elective and 12 nominated members. The Boers thanked Lord Milner but declined the proposition. They declared that the Boer enfranchisement must be commensurate with their stake in the country. (R.)

div.head:
AMERICAN COTTON CROP.
SERIOUS BLOW TO IMPERIAL SCHEMES.

div.p: The gigantic crop of American cotton is regarded as a serious blow to the schemes of growing cotton in Africa and elsewhere in the Empire.
(Reuter.)
The Federation Master Cotton Spinners Association have completed their fusion with the Bolton Spinners Association. The two bodies now represent 26,000,000 spindles. (R.)

div.head:
GORDON-BENNETT CUP.
NEXT RACE AT AUVERGNE.
div.p: The Automobile Club has decided that the next Gordon-Bennett race will take place at Auvergne.
(Reuter.)
The Brindisi Mail will close at the G.P.O., Alexandria, at 8.30 a.m. on Monday.

div.head: EXECUTION AT CAIRO -
div.p: Yesterday Aly El Negoumi suffered the penalty of death at the Appeal Court Prison, Cairo. The murderer killed a native of Houeim, Santu district, last March.

div.head: COTTON WORMS.—
div.p: The Khedivial Agricultural Society intends to ask the Government to draw up a scheme for making natives collect cotton worms, as was done in the case of the locusts recently.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL.-
div.p: On Tuesday, 27th inst., 8 vessels passed through the Canal : 5 British, 1 German, 2 Dutch. The receipts for the day were frs. 165,739.59, bringing up the total receipts trom 1st to 27th inst. to frs. 9,478,611.37.

div.head: MILITARY MARCH.-
div.p: The Mounted Infantry in Cairo wil march from Abbassieh to Sela, in the Fayoum district, between the 2nd and 14th proxo. The approximate strength of the party will be six officers, 100 rank and file, 24 natives, 118 horses, and 4 mules.

div.head: DROWNING ACCIDENT. -
div.p: The body of Alfred Davies, second cook of the S.S. "Rameses," who was drowned in Alexandria harbour on Christmas morning under circumstances already related in our columus, was recovered yesterday and removed to the Deaconesses' Hospital previous to burial.

div.head: AUSTRALIA IN EGYPT.—
div.p: Mr. John B. Gillison, F.I.A., F.F.A., manager for Great Britain and Ireland of the National Mutual Life Association of Australasia, Ltd., who has been staying at Shepheard's Hotel for some weeks past, is returning to England to-day by the Messageries Maritimes steamer from Alexandria. Mr. Gillison has been engaged in organising in Egypt a branch of the important life association which he represents. During next week an office will be opened in the conrt of the Cairo Stock Exchange under the control of Mr. S. de Bilinski..

div.head: OUR NEW JUDGES.
BANQUET TO JUDGE LONG.
div.p: Khedivial decrees were published yesterday moming confirming:

1. The appointment of Mr. A. L. Webb as Under Secretary of State for Irrigation to the Ministry of Public Works, and that of Mr. A.H. Perry as Under-Secretary of State for Public Buildings to the same Ministry.
2. The appointment of Mr. J. E. Marshall to be Counsellor to the Native Court of Appeal.
3. The transfer of Mr. H. Percival, judge of the Native Tribunal, Cairo, to the Alexandria Tribunal, in Mr. Marshall's place.
4. The appointment from January 1, 1905, to the judgeships of the Native Courts of First Instance, of Mr. John Felix Kershaw, barrister-at-law ;
Mr. R. A. Vaux, at present inspector of the Committee of Judicial Surveillance, to Zagazig;
Mr. Charles Blackstone Clapcott, barrister-at law of London, to Assiout;
Mr. Ralph Neville, barrister-at-law of London, to Beni Souet, and
Mr. A. J. Wakeman Long, solicitor of the Supreme Court of London and advocate to the Mixed Court of Appeal, Alexandria, to Tantah.
Hafiz Effendi Hasan is appointed Sub-Mamour of Beni Souef in place of Abd-el-Kerim Bey Hassan, relieved of his functions.

Mr. Neville, one of the new judges appointed to the Native Courts, is the son of Mr. Ralph Nevile, K.C., the well-known Chancery special. He was called to the Bar (Middle Temple) in 1899 and is an LL.B.
Mr. Clapcott is a member of the Chancery Bar, having been called in 1892 (Lincoln's Inn).
Mr. Vaux is another member of Lincoln's Inn and read in the chambers of that distinguished judge and former conveyancing counsel to the Court, Mr. Ingle Joyce. Mr. Vaux was called in 1896.
The departure of Mr. Justice Marshall from Alexandria on the occasion of his translation to the Native Court of Appeal at Cairo took place yesterday.

An interesting ceremony took place at the Khedivial Hotel, Alexandria, last night, when Maitre Demetriades, of the Mixed Courts, gave a banquet in honour of the appointment of Mr. Wakeman Long to a judgeship of 1st Instance in the Native Tribunals. Among those present were Mr. Briscoe, the leader of the English Bar at Alexandria, Maitre Caloyanni and Mr. Preston, of the British Consular Bar and the Mixed Courts, Maitre Mario Vella, of the Mixed Courts, Mr. Frederick Leveaux, of the British Consular Bar, Cairo, etc. After an excellent repast Maitre Demetriades, the genial host, gave a most touching valedictory panegyric on the high professional attainments, stern sense of duty, and other qualities which have gained for Judge Long the esteem and respect of a large circle of friends and acquaintances at Alexandria.
Mr. Demetriades' discourse was followed by an eloquent address by Maitre Mario Vella, who confined his speech to the great reputation which Judge Long had won at the Mixed Courts,
Mr. Briscoe then rose and, in the name of his English colleagues at Alexandria, bewailed the loss which Egypt's commercial capital was about to sustain.

The guest of the evening replied in suitably modest terms in regard to the encomiums of the preceding speakers. He referred to the kind manner in which he had been received by his colleagues, and to the cordial relations which had always existed between his learned brethren and himself. He went on to say that he had no doubt that his successor would be treated in the same kind manner, and expressed his regret that forensically his connection would be severed, but he assured his attentive hearers that he would always retain those ties of friendship and professional respect, which bound him to Alexandria. He referred to the exalted position he was about to occupy in the Egyptian Government service, and stated that he entered upon his new duties in the spirit of a law student--that aspect of a lawyer's career which would remain with him to the end of his days, no matter to what eminence he attained--and quoted the remark of Lord Justice Bowen, one of England's greatest judges, who was wont to say that he had been a law student for 40 years and would remain a law student as long as he lived.

Maitre Caloyanni then added his testimony to the general ability and courtesy of his learned friend and late colleague, and proceeded to draw an interesting comparison between the procedure and methods of English jurisprudence and that of other countries, where the Code Napoleon and Roman Law had been adopted.

Mr. Preston followed with a humorous speech, and confirmed what Judge Long had said as to the invariable sympathy and ungrudging help he had received at the hands of his colleagues when starting in practice in Egypt, referring particularly to the kindness and geniality of Mr. Briscoe, whose health he proposed.
Mr. Briscoe replied in fitting terms. The party did not disperse until a late hour, after a very pleasant and interesting evening.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: H. H. the Khedive, after presiding at the Council of Ministers at Abdeen Palace on Thursday morning, gave private audiences to Sir William Garstin and to Lewa Lord Edward Cecil Pasha, and later in the day to the Sheikh El Jisr of Tripoli (Syria) and to Moh. Bey Beheri, editor of a Moslem newspaper published at Tripoli.
His Highness will preside over the ceremony of the transport of the Kisweh el Mahmal from the Citadel to the Mosque of Saidna Hussein.

div.head: WRECKED PORTUGUESE TRANSPORT.
CREW AT SUEZ.
div.p: Suez, Thursday.---The British India steamer "Ismailia,” which arrived at Suez this morning from India, had on board the captain and crew of the Portuguese transport "Sao Thome," which was wrecked in the Red Sea on the evening of the 24th November last. The transport "Sao Thome” was a vessel of 1,485 tons register, owned by the Empreza Nacional Naviga cao, and under the command of Captain Jose Antono dos Reus. She had been chartered by the Portuguese Government for the conveyance of naval and military details, ammunition, and guns from Lisbon to Macao, and at the time of the wreck had 335 naval and military officers and men on board, in addition to her crew, numbering 76 all told.

At 7 o'clock in the evening of the 24th ult., in clear and fine weather, the steamer ran at full speed on a coral reef on the Farisan bank, not far off the Arabian coast, in the Red Sea. An Arab pilot had been taken to assist in navigating the transport down the Red Sea, and the vessel at the time was making for Perim Straits.

The officers were at dinner when the crash came, the "Sao Thomes" bows being carried up high by the force of the impact. This is considered to have in a manner helped to keep the vessel afloat for a few days. On the evening of the 17th ult., the crew and troops were saved by the S.S. "Clan Mackay" (Cap. Higgins) and conveyed to Aden. A few days later the "Sao Thome" became a total wreck.
The S.S. "Ismailia" is calling specially at Lisbon to land the wrecked crew.

div.head: SHEIKH BARGHOUT.
div.p: Sir William Garstin will probably arrive at Suez to-day, and will embark on H.H.S. Aida for a visit to the new port of Sheikh Barghout. He will probably return on the 18th prox.

div.head: ASSIZE COURTS.
div.p: The projet de loi concerning the Assize Courts will be submitted to the Council of Ministers at their next meeting.

div.head: BUBONIC PLAGUE.
div.p: Yesterday's bulletin records a fresh case at Suez.
To-day's bulletin records 3 fresh cases at Suez (one fatal ) and a similar number in Toukh district.

div.head: CHURCH SERVICES FOR THE MINES
div.p: The Bishop in Jerusalem has directed the Rev. E. H. Blyth, Chaplain at Suez, to pay such occasional visits to the gold mine at Um Rus and to Suakin as his duties at Suez may allow of his doing. "Both sides of the Red Sea" are within the prescribed charge of the Bishop, and there are many English residents at each of these places at the present time.

div.head: CHRISTMAS DAY AT ASSOUAN.
div.p: The services at St. Mark's, Assouan, were bright and hearty. The early celebration was taken by the Rev. G. W. Boyd, of Stepney. assisted by the Rev. A. G. Wise. At the other services and celebration Bishop Morley officiated and preached.

The offertory, amounting to twenty pounds eight shillings, was divided between the Luxor Hospital and the Church Army Winter Relief Fund, London. Mr. Burnett presided ably at the organ, and there was a strong choir of ladies. The church was prettily decorated with palm leaves and oleanders.

div.head: NAVAL NOTES.
div.p: Port-Said, Thursday. – H.M.S. "Cressy," first-class armoured cruiser, 1,200 tons (Captain Henry Tudor), arrived at Port-Saïd on Wednesday night homeward bound from the China station, where she has been relieved by H.M.S. "Hogue." The "Cressy" left this afternoon for Malta,
H.M.S. "Vestal,” screw sloop (Commander Stuart Farquhar), arrived at Port-Saïd on Wednesday morning, also homeward bound from the China station.
H.M.S. "Merlin," screw sloop, is due at Port-Said to-morrow homeward bound from Bombay.

H.M. transport "Sicilia" (Capt. G.H.C. Weston, R.N.R.) arrived at Port-Saïd this morning from Southampton for Bombay. She had 1,328 troops of all ranks on board. Lt.Col. F.A. Cregan, Royal Engineers, is the officer commanding.

div.head: VERDI THEATRE, CAIRO.
div.p: On Wednesday night Dinorah was promised us by the Verdi Theatre management, then came Mignon, and then "Relâche." It seems that during the rehearsal the artistes who had signed an engagement with Mr. G. Ruotolo discovered that he was no longer impresario. Very properly they refused to appear, so for the present there are no performances at the Teatro Verdi.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner "Tabor" sailed from Malta yesterday morning for Tripoli and Alexandria and is due here on Tuesday next, with passengers, mails, and general cargo.
The Moss liner "Philæ" arrived at Liverpool yesterday morning.
The S.S. "Spartan Prince," from Antwerp, left London on Tuesday last, with passengers and general cargo, for Malta and Alexandria.
The S.S. "Grecian Prince " arrived in Manchester from Alexandria on Thursday last.

div.head: CAIRO GRAND HAMMAM.
div.p: Near Shepheard's Continental Hotels.
Turkish Baths, Plain Baths, X Rays, Electric Light Baths.
Massage & Electro-Hydropathic Baths.

div.head: EGYPTIAN SHARE MARKET
div.p: Stocks and shares have during the present week been little influenced by other considerations than the coming Christmas holidays. The black fog of the good old "pea-soup” order, which has prevailed continuously for the last three days and nights, has also kept many of the principal dealers and brokers away ; consequently there is no chance of the market shaking off the holiday garb until the middle of next week. Since our last much has taken place in the political world which must sooner or later have its effect on stock exchange values. According to reliable information, the Powers are sadly disappointed at recent events in Russia. The heads of the Church have played into the hands of the War Party by using their influence to prevent the Tsar from even encouraging the pioneers of reform, as was his personal wish ; so for the present matters have come to a deadlock. If something is not done soon to appease the increasing discontent, we shall see an upheaval, the consequence of which, to Russia, will be too dreadful to contemplate.

All this is retarding the long-wished-for peace. The European Powers recognise that if the end of the war is to result in a lasting peace, and not to be followed by another war nearer home, and possibly in Asia also, then the Powers must have a voice in the final settlement, and all must be in accord therewith.

As regards the course of prices this week, there is little of interest to tell. Egyptian stocks have been, and are still, dull. Agricultural Banks are as low as 9 1/4 and Nationals 21 1/4. Land shares are also easier and Salt and Sodas are a fraction lower at 1 3/4. Daira Sugar are almost the only things which have held their price, keeping firm at 5 15/16, and in face of the dividend just declared are worth buying. The Corporation announce that a dividend at the rate of 3s. per share, less income tax, was declared at the meeting yesterday, payable to holders of share warrants to bearer, on presentation of coupon No. 3, by Messrs. Glyn, Mills, Currie & Co. on and after to-day. The Nile Valley report was not considered altogether satisfactory and the price fell to 2 5/16 the probability of a further issue of shares (part of the unissued capital) being also an adverse factor. At the same time it must be borne in mind that the shares are now in very strong hands, and consequently we are sure to see the development of the mine pushed forward with energy and in a proper manner. The present price, therefore, should offer a fair speculative chance, especially as the general expectation is that we shall see good mining markets early in the New Year. In the foreign market the recent sale in Russian stock has caused a certain amount of uneasiness in Paris. The internal state of affairs in Russia is certainly curious, and should trouble arise there, the effect on speculative markets, through Paris, might be severe. Barring this, the outlook is good, and as far as London is concerned markets are wonderfully good in tone and tendency, although we must not expect much activity until the holidays and the effect thereof have worn off.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The Duke of Connaught's presence in Cairo next month will lend a good deal of attraction to Egypt. His Royal Highness will remain for a short holiday before proceeding to the Sudan in February.
Lady Arthur Russell and Miss Russell are staying in the Fayoum for a few days. They will return afterwards to the Hotel d'Angletérre, Cairo

Baron and Baroness von Humpoldt-Dachroeden gave a delightful dance as the German Consulate, Alexandria, last night to the captain, officers, and midshipmen if the German training-ship "Stosch." All the leading members of the German colony were present.
The marriage of Dr. Rucker Jehisch, German Diplomatic Agent at Cairo, to Countess Thyra Grote will take place at Berlin next month.

A marriage has been arranged and will take place on the 19th proxo., between Mr. Ludwig Schneider, of the well-known German-Egyptian firm of Schneider and Rothacker, and Miss Else Pastor, of Crefeld. Miss Pastor is the daughter of Mr. Carl Pastor, a large railway material manufacturer. They will spend the honeymoon in Italy and will arrive at Alexandria at the end of February.
M. Barois, French member of the Railway Board, has had the grand gold medal of the National Agricultural Society of France bestowed upon him in recognition of his work on Egyptian irrigation.
The Khedive has bestowed the rank of Moutemaiz on Herz Bey, the chief engineer to the Committee for the Conservation of Memorials of Arabic Art.
Mr. Jacques Isaac Aghion has contributed £1 to the funds of the Rudolph Home as a dispensation from paying New Year calls.

We regret to announce the death of Mr. Anthony Darmanin, which occurred yesterday afternoon, at the age of 53 years. The deceased gentleman had been in the service of the firm of Messrs. Allen, Alderson & Co., Ltd., Alexandria, since 1867, and was held in the very highest esteem by his chiefs. Deceased leaves a widow and two daughters. The funeral will take place this afternoon at 4 p.m.

div.head: FOOTBALL
SAINT ANDREW FOOTBALL CLUB.
div.p: Owing to the extreme difficulty experienced at this time of the year in getting together a representative eleven, the game arranged between "C" Company, Royal Berks, and the Saint Andrew Football Club, has been postponed till the 7th of January,

This same difficulty was encountered last week, but the match between the Army Temperance Association and Saint Andrews, having been already postponed one week, was played off. Saint Andrews did what they could, putting a scratch eleven on the field, but not half of the players were members of the club. In spite of this fact, however, and the inclemency of the weather, the game was a good one. The Army Temperance team played splendidly, but the condition of the ground latterly somewhat upset the calculations of the players. The "Seats" were the first to open the score, but shortly before half-time, and after some tussling, the Army Temperance managed to get a goal from a corner kick. At half-time the score stood one all. Towards the end of the second half the play was not quite so balanced, the homesters having rather the best of the game. They eventually scored another goal, thus being able to claim a victory of two goals to one.

div.head: TEWFIKIA v. KHEDIVIA SCHOOLS.
div.p: After a fast game, in which the Khedivia team showed better footwork and combination than their opponents, the Tewfikia boys were yesterday beaten by 4 goals to 1. In the first half the Khedivia scored 2 goals to nil. The Tewfikia had more of the play in the second half and scored a goal towards the finish. There was a large and enthusiastic audience of pupils and old boys, and the grand-stand was full of visitors, among whom we may mention the Earl of Cromer, the Minister of Public Instruction, Mr. Dunlop, Mr. and Mrs. Elliot, Mr. and Mrs. Sharman, Mr. T Machell, Dr. Keatinge, Mr. Webb, C.M.C. Mr. and Mrs. Tatton Browne,Mr. Aspinall, and many others. An excellent tea was kindly dispensed by Mrs. Sharman in the grand-stand.

div.head: R. M. A. v. R. A. M. C.
div.p: The above teams met for the first time this season, at Ras-el-Tin yesterday. From the start the gunners pressed hard and very soon found the net. Half time came with the score : R. M. A. 4, R. A. M. C., nil. In the second half the R. A.M. C. played a better game but were unable to score. Result: R. M. A. 7 goals, R. A. M. C., nil.

div.head: E.T. C. v. "C" COMPANY BERSHIRE REGIMENT.
div.p: These teams were opposed at Sidi Gaber on Wednesday. E. T. C. started down the slope, and three minutes from the start got their first goal. Nothing further was scored until close on half-time, when Thurston found the net from a fine centre by Blythman. Halftime E. T.C. 2, Berks 0. The second half proved more even, only one goal being scored, and that by the Berks, from a melee in front of goal. Incledon played a fine game for the Exiles. Result E. T. C. 2, Berks 1.
The following played for the E. T. C.: Goal, Harrison; backs, Lees and Sedowick; halves, Townsend, Incledon, and Barnes; forwards, Blythman, Thurston, Byrne, Steele, and R. B. McLean,

div.head: COMMISSION MUNICIPALE
div.p: (Communication officielle)
La Commission Municipale s'est réunie le 28 décembre 1904 à 4 b. p.m. sous la présidence de M. Ambroise A. Ralli.

Lecture est donnée d'une lettre de S.E. le Ministre de l'Intérieur du 27 courant, informant que la Municipalité lui ayant fait savoir qu'elle n'syait pas d'objection à ce que le Gouvernement doppât des ing tructions directes à M. Chataway, s'il consentait à le désigner comme son délégué Buprès de la Compagnie des Eaux, il ap prouve en conséquence cette désignation.

Communication est ensuite donnée d'ane lettre du 24 novembre de la Oompagnie des Eaux i form unt que dans le but de fa: ciliter l'emploi d'une plus grande quantité d'eau pour les besoins publics, son Conseil & décidé de réduire de 20 à 15 cent, par m.c. le prix de l'eau pour les besoins mu. nicipaux, au delà d'un paiement annuel de L E 6,000.

La Commission accepte avec remerciements la décision de la Compagnie. A ce sujet, dee propositions formulées par M. Escoffier coacernant l'installation d'abreuvoire pour les bêtes et par M. Zouro pour des démarches à faire tondant à ce que, au lieu de la fourniture d'eu par compteurs pour les besoins de la Ville, l'eau soit fourpie à robinet libre à un chiffre forfaitaire, Bont renvoyées à l'étude de la Délégation.

Communication est égal-ment donnée d'une lettre du Ministère de l'Intérieur informant que l'avis du Département des travaux publics ne lui.est pas encore parvenu au sujet du collecteur Est, et qu'il - vient d'écrire à nouveau pour que la ré. ponge du dit Départemeat lui soit envoyés le plus tôt possible.

La Commission compte que cette réponse ne tardera pas, vu l'urgence que prés ante la construction du dit co'l cteur, qui sera mis en service lors de l'achèvement des filtres, qui aura lieu en Mai pro. chain.
Le Commission approuve le nouveau projet de règlement sur les chiens et la rage, élaboré par le Comité spécial et qui comporte, certain 8 modifications au projet antérieur.

Ce règlement presorit le paiement d'una taxe de P.T. 5 par chien et le port d'un collier avec pl-que numérotée, le molèle de celle-ci devent être arrêté par la Délégation, Oe Ocl è ze prescrira d'aprè: les cir. constabes si les chiens doivent être mu. Belés, ou tenus en laisse, ou si les deux mesures do vent être appliquées à la fois. Les chiens trouvés non munis du collier avec plaque seront saisis et conduits à la fourrière, de même que les chiens trouvés non muselés ou ciroulant libr«8 aux époques ou le musellement ou la tenue en laisse est prescrite.

La Municipalité se réserve le droit de procéder à tout moment à la destruction ar l'empoisonnement ou autrement des hiens errants. L-8 cas suspects de rage loivent être portés immé liatement à la Onnaiegence de l'autorité administrative. Le règlement sera affiché.

Après un échang- d'idées au sujet de la iemande de M Théodorides concernant la sréation d'un service de camions automobiles, la Commission, avant toute décision, prie le Comité du Contentieux Municipal l'étudier la question au point de vue légal; le son côté le service teebnique aura à étu. lier dans l'intervalle la question de l'atili. sation du caoutchouo pour l.s roue: de ces samions et la vitesse maxima qu'il y a lieu de leur imposer.

M. Giymenopoulo s'offre de prêter à 1. Municipalité pour toutes expérieno 8 qu'elle voudrait faire à ce sujet, un camion auto. mobile qu'il a commaodé en Eąrope pour ses besoins particuliers et qui arrivera incessamment.

Le Président expose la question de la tour dite de-Romains; il dit qq la Délégation poar des considérations hygiénigies et esthétiques insiste pour l'enlèvement de cette tour qui ne présente aucun intérêt archéologique mais le Comité de conservation des monuments de l'art Arabe en demande le maintien ainsi qu'il résulte d'une lettre du Mi: nistère de l'Intérieur adressée à ce sujet à la Municipalité.

Après un échange d'idées, la CommigBion partageant à l'unanimité la manière de voir de la Délégation et considérant que la tour constitue dans son état actuel una sorte de dépotoir, ébréchée qu'elle est de tous côtés, qu'elle est dénuée de tout inté. rêt historique et que sa solidité même est compromise, déci le d'ineister suprès du Gouvernement pour sa démolition, tout en conservant les fondations pour l'établissement à titre de vestige de son emplacement exact.

Vu la lettre du 11 novembre du Comité du Victoria Collega demandant l'adhésion de ja Municipalité pour la vente de 1468 m 76, de terrain cédé à ce Comité par la Ville, près de la gire de Ramleh, en même temps que les terroigs à lai cédés par le Gouvernement et ce en vue de déplacer le Collège ailleurs, la Commission en considération du, bat philanthropique du dit établissement, décide d'adhérer à la demande du Comité et ancepte d'avance les condi. tions que le Gouvernement croira devoir fixer pour cette cession.

Abordant la question de la règlementa tion et de l'établissement d'une taxe sur les] marchands ambulants, la Commission prend connaissance de l'avis négatif donné par la Délégation à l'ancienne proposition y relative de M. Cumbo.

Celui-ci répond aux objections de la Dé. légation et fait valoir que s'il demande une règl-mentation, ce n'est pas en vue de gupprimer cette corporation ausgi digne d'in térêt que les autres, mais afin que soit la Municipalité, soit la police, puisse avoir une action directe contre les dits mar. chande, qui,en l'état actuel des choses, abusent de la tolérance qui leur est octroyée, en encombrant les rues au grand détriment de la circulation. Ce qui justifi, d'autre part la taxe qu'il propose et qui est très minime, c'est d'un côté la concurrence que les marchands ambulants font aux boutiquiers et de l'autre le fait qu'ils utilisent la voio pablique. Exempter les charrettes de des marchands sous prétexte qu'il s'agit d'ane olagse peu p ivilégiée, serait faire de la mauvaise administration, attendu que o'est un système qui pourrait ouvrir le porte à beaucoup de réclamations de cette nature ausi justifiées. Bien entendu, il n'est pas question des colporteurs mais uni. quement des charrettes des marchands ambulants.
Une digoussion s'engago, à la suite de la quelle la Commission, par 8 voix contre 7, adopte le prinoipe de la taxe sauf à arrêter ultérieurement les détails d'application.
Une proposition de M. Padoa Bey, au sujet d'une question relative aux employés révoqués par rapport aux attributions du fonds de prévoyance, est renvoyée au Comité du Contentieux.
Le séance est levée à 8 h. p.m.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demie)

L'Amérique nous étant parvenue avec une baisse insignifiante de 4 à 5 points pour NewYork et une hausse de 2, points pour la Nouvelle-Orléans, notre marché des cotons s'est amélioré; comme conséquence, nos valeurs ont immédiatement repris sur toute la ligne, ce qui montre assez combien un relèvement graduel des cours est assuré si la hausse des cotons s'accentue.

Les affaires restent cependant clairsemées. Les seules valeurs un peu mouvementées sont, pour le moment du moins, la Banque Nationale, la Salt & Soda et l’Agricole. L'entrain gagnera certainement les autres, dès que Londres et Paris, encore sous le coup de la debacle de ces jours derniers, auront repris de la confiance dans les valeurs égyptiennes.
La clôture est toute en hausse. La Nationale atteint 221, l'Agricole 911, la Delta Land 318, la Daïra 211, la Salt & Soda 38, la Banque d'Athènes 119, la Delta Light 14 ex, etc.
La tendance du marché est excellente.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET.
KEARSLEY AND CUNNINGHAM'S WEEKLY REPORT.
div.p: Egyptian Cotton has been in very limited demand this week, and current qualities, of both "Brown” and "Upper," are reduced 3/16 @ 7a per. lb. "Fine" and "Extra Fine" are unchanged.
In Futures a good business has been done ; the following are the latest values : Dec. 7.2 Feb. 6.39 Apl. 6.34 June 6.32 Jan. 6.47 Mar. 6.36 May 6.33 July 6.31

AMERICAN FUTURES. The market this week has experienced a further serious depression, and values have fallen sharply ; to-day's closing values being 23 @ 21 points below those of last Thursday. The depression has been chiefly due to a heavy liquidation by the "Bulls" together with aggressive manipulation by the New York Bear Clique. Crop movements continue on a free scale, but not larger than was anticipated, and only in accordance with Crop estimates of 12 millions or thereabouts. There is an absence of speculation, and consumers having secured large supplies are holding aloof until the market assumes a steadier appearance. Prices may be forced down temporarily but we consider that present values are low enough, and it may even eventually prove that they have been forced too low.
The latest quotations are - Delivery : - Dec. 3:93 Feb./Mar. 4.01 May/June 4.11 Dec./Jan. 3.93 Mar./Apl. 4.05 June/July 4.13 Jan./Feb. 3.96 Apl./May 4.08 July/Aug. 4.15

div.head: Société des Téléphones.
div.p: Le Téléphone Company of Egypt Ld., s'emprese d'informer seg abonnés et le publio que les communications téléphoniques Oaire-Alexandrie et vice-versa étaient interrompues hier 29 Déoembre de 7 heures du matin jusqu'à 1 heure 10 m. du soir; après quoi une des lignes a été réta. blie. Ces lignes sont la propriété exclusive de l'Etat et cédées par loyer à la Société, mais cette dernière ne peut pas être responsable pour le bon fonctionnement des lignes vu qu'elles sont entretenues par le Télégraphe Egyptien. Elle regrette quand même les inconvénients qu'ont dû subir les abonnés par suite de ces interruptione. Aujourd'hui depuis 8 heures 80 a.m. les lignes sont en état de bon fonctionnement.

div.head: LAND VALUES IN EGYPT.
div.p: (Concluded).
General Conditions.

The foregoing conditions are all matters of more or less recent date, and did not exist before, or if they did, in a much less, marked degree. A little consideration of them will show that the increased value of land in Egypt is based on very solid foundations, and that it is no mere "booming” up land to an inflated value. A Nile that never fails, though there may be good years and bad, and a reliable climate Tender agriculture far easier and safer in Egypt than in other countries.

A clear political atmosphere, so far as Egypt is concerned, now renders possible the study of still more engineering works to make the security of irrigation doubly sure. The finances of the country for the last 10 years or more have averaged, in round figures : revenue, 11 million pounds ; expenditure, 10 millions ; surplus, 1 million. Land tax has been reduced and many other burdens were found onerous. No other country can show equally prosperous budgets. Every year an amount of gold comes into the country which does not go out again. This accumulation is some 12 million pounds in the last 5 years ; presumably largely in fellaheen hands.
Price of Land.

Having considered the causes which have contributed to the increased value of land, it is necessary to see what the price actually is before it can be called inflated. Land in Egypt when in proper order will produce from 3 to 8 kantars of cotton: per feddan. Low lands semo-reclaimed will be under 3, but that is temporary, and exceptional areas will give 10 kantars and over.

A very safe valuation is to say land is worth L.E. 15 for every kantar of cotton it will produce, and when this valuation is applied, and probable land tax deducted, it will be seen that the return is about 7%. It is assumed that half the land is under cotton. Whilst the fellah for the last three or four years has been getting P.T. 300 to P.T. 400 per kantar for his cotton, the price assumed is P.T. 250, an average which would have held good for the last 15 years. This price is for the fellah's kantar, containing the seed and weighing 315 rotls, producing nominally 100 rotls of clean cotton, but really producing 105-110 rotls.

Three-kantar land worth L.E. 45 per feddan cultivated halt in cotton produces 14 over the whole area; at 250 PT per kantar, P.T. 375. Deduct land tax, probably P.T. 50 ; net recurn P.T. 325 per feddau. On L.E. 45 the return of 325 P.T. is 7%.
Five-kantar land worth L.E. 75 produces 24 kantars, worth P.T. 625 ; less land tax P.T. 5 ; net P.T. 550, which is also 7 %.
Eight-kautar land worth L. E. 120, produces 4 kantars worth L.E. 10; less land tax P.T. 150; net P.T. 850, and this is also 7 %.

No deduction is made for expenses of cultivation. The land can be let so that the proprietor receives the whole of the cotton, the tenant getting the maize and all the winter crop of berseem, barley, wheat, beans, and catch crops of vegetables. These crops keep aim and his cattle, and cover cost of production.

There is very little land that could be bought just now on the basis of £15 per kantar of Yield; but a good deal could be had at £20 basis. That would reduce the return on capital to 5 %, but it must be borne in mind that the price of cotton is taken as P.T. 250 whilst the last three years it has averaged, say, 350 P.T.
When one hears of land being sold at £150 per feddau it is probably land which produces about 7 kantars of cotton. At the average price of cotton for the last three years it would yield 6%

The earning power of money in Egypt is rapidly decreasing, and assuming, what might be taken for a fact, that the purchase price of and now is 15 years purchase of the net rental, deducting land tax, a basis of 6.66 % return, it may be prophesied that in another five years investors will purchase on 20 years Purchase and be satisfied with 5 % return.

Inflated prices cannot be proved, nor does Examination of the whole question lead one to believe that they exist as a general rule. It may be freely admitted that there are cases where too high prices have been paid : these are due to natives wishing to add field to field, and dying heavily for neighbouring land end of seeking better investment farther Return on capital influences them less, regardless of price, a particular land they fancy.
Land Crisis.

Remaining for the moment that cotton fell in price from any cause, is there going a great crash in land values ? When egyptian cotton is P.T. 200 per kantar, American cotton is equally down, and is on the verge of being cultivated at a loss. That is a great safeguard. The cost of production elsewhere gives Egypt a margin.

Present prosperous times give the fellah projector a surplus which he invests in land, and in land only. If his position is affected, his buying power is curtailed for the time being, The indebtedness of the fellaheen is an unknown quantity, but undoubtedly it is much less than formerly. The requirements of the fellah beyond what his land produces are exceedingly few, only tobacco, coffee, sugar and clothes. A substantial man of $500 a year may spend only £50 per annum, and the produce of his land consumed by him and his family, is only that of a few feddans.

Properties are not burdened with fixed payments when a man dies; the division is in kirats or twenty-fourths. The widow may get 3 kirats, sons 4, daughters 1, and so on, and if there is shrinkage in the annual revenue, the sums payable to all the beneficiaries shrink in proportion. In England landed estates are burdened with mortgages, widows' allowances. provision to younger sons and daughters ; and when severe agricultural depression occurs, the unfortunate proprietor has to pay all these calls in full, and has little or nothing left.

In Egypt properties are not so heavily engaged and subject to other calls, and a proprietor if he could not meet a sinking fund in extinction of his debt, should at least be able to pay interest even during bad times. This year in Beheira Province the cotton crop is short, and some borrowers will have difficulty in meeting their debts. The 6 million feddans of cultivated land in Egypt are worth, at a low average of £50, the sum of three hundred million pounds. The amount of mortgages is unknown, but can it be 10% of this ; say 30 million pounds? The Banks, excepting those which are Land Loan Banks, do not lend on land, and even if they did, the gross capital of all the Egyptian Banks does not approach the amount. Nor is it likely that private loans would make up the amount. The bulk of the land then is unburdened, and if mortgages were foreclosed the earth-hunger inherent in every Egyptian fellah or townsman would soon cause absorption of any land put on the market.
Conclusion.

It has been shown that prices are not inflated, as the rise in price of land is based on new improved conditions, amply warranting the advance. At present prices the return is distinctly good ; if cotton keeps up, land is not within 40 % of its top value. Even if cotton comes to a moderate price, the prosperity of the country will warrant land being sold on a 5 % basis, or 20 years' purchase. Land being the only investment for the natives, the boom will continue. As to a crisis and tall in prices, the land is held to so very large an extent unburdened, and by proprietors who are permanent holders from father to son, that decreased value only affects their annual income. The comparatively small area of burdened land, even if thrown on the market, would be quickly absorbed and some few speculators would lose, or rather fail to make expected profits. The lenders unless they had been exceedingly rash would secure their loan, which was only probably 60 % of' value at date of mortgage.

div.head: The Nile Valley Company, LIMITED.
DIRECTORS' REPORT.
div.p: The directors have issued their annual report and balance sheet from the date of the incorporation of the company to 31st July, 1904.

FINANCIAL.--The profit and loss account shows a balance of profit carried forward amounting to £585 178. 5d, after making - substantial and ample allowance for depreciation of machinery and plant, buildings, &c. It is gratifying to the directors to be able to report that the gold won, and the other receipts, have sufficed not only to meet all current expenses on the mine, and administration expenses in London, but to enable this provision for depreciation to be made, and still to carry forward a small sum to the current financial year.

The company's cash position is satisfactory, when it is observed that there are still 46,993 shares unissued. It is anticipated that these shares will be issued during the next few months, and that the capital necessary for thoroughly testing the propositions referred to below will thus be obtainable. Every effort is being made to keep expenses as low as possible. Experiments with the object of discovering the cheapest and most suitable fuel are still being made, for it must be borne in mind that the conditions of the Um Garaiart mine are certainly unique.

PROPERTY AND UM GARAIART MINE.-Since the company took over the property from the original Nile Valley Company, great changes have taken place on the mine at Um Garaiart. The disastrous fire which occurred a few days after the company took possession destroyed many of the buildings and the greater part of the machinery. These have been replaced ; in the former case with substantial additions ; and with greater power in the latter. The fire caused great delay and hindrance in the pursuing of mining work, but happily its effects have now been overcome. The various reports have been published from time to time, as they have been received from the property, and periodical reports have been sent out to individual shareholders, so that each may be kept informed as far as is possible of how the work has been proceeding at the mine. A good idea may be gathered of the work done, and in progress, by reference to the report and plans of the company's engineers, Messrs. Lake and Currie, and the report of the mine manager, Mr. John M. Buckwith. Great difficulties have had to be contended with owing to the large flow of water encountered in No. 1 shaft in February last, which necessitated a complete reorganisation of pumping machinery. l'his difficulty has been overcome ; mining operations are now in full swing, and with ordinary fortune should be continued without hindrance. A 5-stamp battery is now being erected, and will, it is hoped, commence crushing in January. Another 5-stamp has been ordered. and the company will therefore have 10 stamps at work before very long.

REST OF THE CONCESSION.-Such close attention having been paid to the Um Garaiart mine, the management has not been able to do as much development on other mines, or to prospect the concession as fully as they could have wished. Several other hopeful proposi. tions in addition to Um Garaiart, are known to exist on the concussion, notably at Absciel, Homari, and Alchani.

ABSCIEL. —This is a very promising copper mine. A shaft has been sunk to water level (97 feet) when a crosscut was put in intersecting the vein, which ultimately proved to be 38 feet in width, giving from 5 per cent. to 10 per cent. of copper. Work was stayed here owing to the necessity of pumping plant before the lode can be explored at depth, but it is proposed as soon as possible to test the lode by means of diamond drills.
HOMARI AND ALCHANI. — These are both gold propositions, on which but little work has been so far done. This little, however, shows them to be well worth attention at & later date.

FURTHER DISCOVERIES.-Several other old workings are on the concession, and rumours are brought in by the natives of the existence of precious stones on the north-western corner. Prospecting expeditions will be sent out from the main camp from time to time. The directors are pleased to announce that the Egyptian Government have agreed to prolong the prospecting rights over the whole of the concession for a further period of two years from the 30th April next.

SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES.-Both the subsidiary companies, the North Nile Valley, Limited, and the Nile Valley-Block E," Limited, are actively engaged in development and mining. The North Nile Valley, Limited, has applied for, and been granted a mining lease for 30 years, renewable for a further period of 15 years, and the results on Block E have warranted that company making an application for a lease, which is now in course of being forwarded to the Egyptian Government.

Nile GOLDFIELDS, 'LIMITED.-This company is working a large succession to the immediate north of the Nile Valley. Though, so far, nothing of any great importance has been opened up, very promising ancient workings at El Hudiare being investigated, and promise well. El Hudi is admirably situated about 30 miles from Assouan ; can be economically developed, and has a strong reef some 10 feet in width.

SHARE HOLDINGS.-Beyond the subsidiaries just mentioned, the company is not interested in any other concern ; the directors being of opinion that the company's resources should be conserved for the working of the concession in Egypt

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN SALT & SODA COMPANY,Ltd.
div.p: NOTICE is hereby given, that an Extraordinary General Meeting of the Egyptian Salt & Soda Company, Limited, will be held at the Registered Office of the Company, 6, Old Jewry, E.O., on the twelth day of January 1905 at 11 o'clock in the forenoon when the subjoined ex- traordinary and special resolutions will be pro- posed.

Should the special resolution be passed by the required majority it will be submitted for confirmation as a special resolution to a second extraordinary meeting which will be held on the 27th January 1905, at 11 o'clock in the forenoon at the Registered Office of the Com- pany.
SPECIAL RESOLUTION.
That the Articles of Association be altered as follows namely:
a) In Article 34 the words "registered office or the Company's offices in Cairo" shall be substituted for the word "office."
b) In Article 43 (-1-) after the words "except upon" add the words "a request of an allottee on an allotment of shares or upon."
c) 43 (4). The words "allottees or" shall be added after the words "save as aforesaid."
d) In Article 61 the words "in Cairo" shall be added in the 2nd and last lines after the word "place."
e) In Article 63 the word "to be held in Cairo" shall be added in after the word "meeting."
f) Article 55 after the word "meeting" in the second line and after the word "held" in the last line add "in Cairo."

g) In article 82 the words "shall be deposited at such place or places in Cairo as shall be appointed for that purpose in the notice con- vening the meeting" shall be substituted for the words "shall be deposited at the registered office of the Company."

h) In Article 34 the word "not" shall be deleted and add after the words "such warrants" the words "upon depositing the certificate entitling them to vote with the instrument of proxy and the power of attorney (if any) under which it is signed, in the manner set forth in article 82."
i) In Article 92 the figures "150" and "300" shall be substituted for the figures "250" and "500" respectively.
j) In Article 102 the words "in Cairo" shal be added after the words "office of the Com- pany."
k) In Article 107 add at the end of the ar- ticle the words "the meetings of Directors shall be held in Cairo."

l) In Article 114 the words "the business of the Company shall be managed by the Direc- tors in and from Cairo only" shall be substituted for the words "the management of the business of the Company shall be vested in the Directors."
m) In Article 136 the words "the seal shall be kept in Cairo by the Directors" shall be sub- stituted for the words "the seal shall be in the custody of the Directors."

n) In article 117 the last sentence shali be cancelled and the following shall be added "The books of account, except in so far as may be otherwise required by the Companies Acts shall be kept at such place in Cairo as the Di- rectors may determine."
o) In Article 150 the words "or Egypt" shall be added in the second and fourth lines after the word "Kingdom."
p) In Article 151 the words "or Egypt" shall be added after the word "Kingdom" and the words "registered office or the Office in Cairo" shall be substituted for the word "office."

Shareholders holding Share Warrants to Bearer who wish to attend the General Meeting of the Company must first deposit their Bearer Warrants, together with a statement of their names and addresses, either with the following Banks, in Cairo and Alexandria: The National Bank of Egypt, Crédit Lyonnais, Anglo-Egyptian Bank, Banque Impérial Otto- mane, Bank of Egypt, ten clear days before the date of the General Meeting, viz., not later than the 2nd Jan. 1905, or with the National Bank of Egypt Agency (4 and 5, King William St.) or the Registered Office of the Company (6, Old Jewry, E.C.) viz. not later than the 9th Jan. 1905, the Share Warrants remaining so deposited until after the General Meeting and Confirmatory Meeting (if any) shall have been held.
Each Depositer will receive a Certificate of Deposit in exchange for the Share Warrants deposited and a Ticket of Admission which he must produce at the Meeting.

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: Société Anonyme
Capital 250,000,000 de francs
Entièrement Versés
Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
